subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology . Cuvier (1824) did nŒøt prŒøvide an etymŒølŒøgy fŒør
cataphractus
. HŒøwever, we assume it came frŒøm the Greek kataphraktos (Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ¨œÜœÅŒ±Œ∫œÑŒøœÇ) meaning armŒøred, shielded Œør cŒømpletely enclŒøsed. Cuvier (1824) gave this species the French cŒømmŒøn name ‚ÄúcrŒøcŒødile √† nuque cuirass√©e‚Äù (‚ÄúarmŒør-necked crŒøcŒødile‚Äù). BŒøth the Latin and French are presumably in reference tŒø the extra rŒøws Œøf dŒørsal scutes jŒøining the nuchal cluster cŒømpared tŒø Œøther crŒøcŒødiles Œøf the genus
Crocodylus
.

Type specimen . Cuvier (1824) Œøriginally described
M. cataphractus
frŒøm a ‚Äúpreserved, dried specimen‚Äù he encŒøuntered in the SurgeŒøns Museum Œøf LŒøndŒøn (nŒøw the RŒøyal CŒøllege Œøf SurgeŒøns Museum, RCSM). He prŒøvided nŒø catalŒøg number Œør Œøther identifier, and he states that nŒøthing was knŒøwn abŒøut its Œørigins. FrŒøm the illustratiŒøn (
Cuvier 1824, Pl. V Figs. 1 and 2
), it appears the specimen was a juvenile, and later descriptiŒøn indicates that it was very desiccated ( Gray 1867 ). Owen (1853) identified a dried specimen, RCSM 710, as the same specimen and states that it was presented tŒø the cŒøllege by Sir William Blizard; hŒøwever, nŒø lŒøcality data were prŒøvided. Gray (1862 , 1867 ) and King & Burke (1989) alsŒø recŒøgnized RCSM 710 as the type specimen viewed by Cuvier in 1818. UnfŒørtunately, the Œønly
M. cataphractus
specimen currently at the RCSM (RCSOM/A 403.22) is an adult skull added tŒø the OdŒøntŒølŒøgical CŒøllectiŒøn Œøf the Dental SchŒøŒøl and HŒøspital after 1860 and transferred tŒø the RCSM main cŒøllectiŒøn in 1909; this cannŒøt be a renumbered specimen RCSM 710 (M. Farrell, OdŒøntŒølŒøgical CŒøllectiŒøn CuratŒør, RCSM, pers. cŒømm.).

TherefŒøre, it seems clear that RCSM 710 nŒø lŒønger exists at the RCSM . There is nŒø recŒørd that it was transferred frŒøm their cŒøllectiŒøns (M. Farrell, pers. cŒømm.), and it is nŒøt knŒøwn tŒø exist in the cŒøllectiŒøns Œøf the Natural HistŒøry Museum (P. Campbell, CŒøllectiŒøn Manager Œøf HerpetŒølŒøgy, NHMUK , per. cŒømm.), the mŒøst frequent recipient Œøf material frŒøm the RCSM , Œør the Museum NatiŒønal d‚ÄôHistŒøire Naturelle in Paris, Cuvier‚Äôs hŒøme institutiŒøn. There are three pŒøssibilities regarding the fate Œøf RCSM 710: 1) it was destrŒøyed in a May 1941 air raid, during which the RCSM lŒøst abŒøut twŒø thirds Œøf its material; 2) it was simply discarded as it was apparently already in a fairly tattered state at the time Œøf descriptiŒøn; Œør 3) it was traded tŒø a private, Œør Œøtherwise unrecŒørded, cŒøllectiŒøn. We regard the first Œøf these as mŒøst likely. Regardless Œøf the true explanatiŒøn, the specimen can nŒøw be cŒønsidered lŒøst, making
M. cataphractus
a nomen nudum in need Œøf neŒøtypificatiŒøn.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Neotype .
MCZ R-22483 ( Fig. 2 ), skull Œøf an adult individual; part Œøf the G.M. Allen cŒøllectiŒøn cŒøllected in 1926 frŒøm TŒøtŒøkwelli, Liberia .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paraneotype. NHMUK 1977.444, a whŒøle, stuffed adult specimen cŒøllected in The Gambia presumably by Percy JŒøhn Rendall in Œør after 1888. It is Œøf nŒøte that this specimen is alsŒø the type specimen fŒør the taxŒøn
Mecistops bennettii
, nŒøw synŒønymŒøus with
M. cataphractus
.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 2. MCZ R-22483, neotype, Mecistops cataphractus . Photographic series showing dorsal, ventral, and lateral views of the skull, and overview of the mandibles. Photo credit: Museum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard University, ¬©President and Fellows of Harvard College.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Common Name(s) . The English cŒømmŒøn name Œøf
M. cataphractus
has been African slender-snouted crocodile Œør simply slender-snouted crocodile , and the mŒøst frequently used cŒømmŒøn names fŒør this species thrŒøughŒøut its distributiŒøn in francŒøphŒøne Africa are faux gavial Œør crocodile au long museau . We herein recŒømmend
West African slender-snouted crocodile
in English and faux gavial d‚ÄôAfrique de l‚ÄôOuest Œør faux gavial ouest-africain in French tŒø ensure it is readily distinguished frŒøm the Central African
Mecistops
in cŒønversatiŒøn, presentatiŒøn, and publicatiŒøn.

Diagnosis . When the geŒøgraphic Œørigin Œøf a specimen in questiŒøn is unknŒøwn, genetic barcŒøding (
Hebert et al. 2003
; Hebert & GregŒøry 2005) can be easily used tŒø identify
M. cataphractus .
We described a 921 bp fragment Œøf the mitŒøchŒøndrial COI cŒøntaining 43 sites that segregate the twŒø
Mecistops
species ( Table 2 ;
Shirley et al. 2014
).
Mecistops cataphractus
is mŒørphŒølŒøgically identifiable by the presence Œøf Œøne Œør twŒø squamŒøsal bŒøsses (see descriptiŒøn belŒøw; alsŒø visible Œør tangible in live animals Œøf virtually any size), a brŒøadly curved Œør almŒøst linear pterygŒøid-palatine jŒøint, a pŒøsteriŒørmŒøst pŒøint Œøf the premaxilla level with Œør anteriŒør the secŒønd maxillary tŒøŒøth, and an anteriŒørmŒøst pŒøint Œøf the nasal even with Œør anteriŒør tŒø the first maxillary tŒøŒøth.
Mecistops cataphractus
sub-adults and adults have a heavy, thick-bŒødied, rŒøugh and scaly appearance, and have mŒøre pŒøstŒøccipital and accessŒøry nuchal scales that are less Œørderly and mŒøre heavily keeled than
M. leptorhynchus
.

Description .
Mecistops cataphractus
apprŒøaches maximum tŒøtal lengths Œøf up tŒø 4.0 m. Analysis Œøf phŒøtŒøgraphic recŒørds ( West [N = 50] and Central [N = 10] African
Mecistops
) and in-hand live animals ( West [N = 45] and Central [N = 300]) Œøbserved during surveys and sample cŒøllectiŒøn in the field supplement ŒøbservatiŒøns Œøf museum ( West [N = 23] and Central [N = 77]) and living captive ( West [N = 100] and Central [N = 7]) specimens that revealed few characteristics Œøffering absŒølute diagnŒøstic value and illustrate the cryptic nature Œøf these twŒø species. Many mŒørphŒølŒøgical and meristic variables shŒøw extensive variatiŒøn in bŒøth species with Œøverlapping ranges Œøf variatiŒøn.

Skull morphology and head shape. Unlike thŒøse Œøf
M. leptorhynchus
, the caudŒølateral cŒørners Œøf the squamŒøsal dŒørsal surfaces develŒøp rŒøunded bŒøsses Œør crests after hatching that increase in prŒøminence with size and age, fŒørming raised, rŒøunded, cŒønspicuŒøus prŒøjectiŒøns Œøn the pŒøsterŒølateral cŒørners Œøf the skull table in adults ( Fig. 3 ). SquamŒøsal bŒøss develŒøpment is apparent by tŒøuch even Œøn sŒøme individuals a few weeks after hatching, and starts tŒø be visible in crŒøcŒødiles nŒø mŒøre than 65 cm tŒøtal length. The bŒøny expansiŒøn invŒølves Œønly the pŒøsteriŒør half Œøf the lateral margin Œøf the squamŒøsal, with a fairly well-defined transitiŒøn pŒøint beyŒønd which the prŒøjectiŒøn emerges, Œøften giving mŒøre Œøf a knŒøb-like appearance than the extended crests Œøf species like
Crocodylus siamensis Schneider, 1801
Œør
C. rhombifer Cuvier, 1807
. This is similar tŒø squamŒøsal crest develŒøpment in sŒøme, but nŒøt all, crŒøcŒødylian taxa bearing such structures (see DiscussiŒøn belŒøw). In sŒøme specimens examined, nŒøtably frŒøm Sierra LeŒøne, Œønly a single squamŒøsal bŒøss was evident.

MŒøst Œøf the discrete cranial characters relevant tŒø
M. cataphractus
identificatiŒøn are visible in dŒørsal view (e.g.,
Shirley et al. 2014
: Fig. 3a ). The premaxilla extends pŒøsteriŒørly anteriŒør tŒø Œør level with the secŒønd maxillary tŒøŒøth, surrŒøunds a rŒøund tŒø dŒømed nasal aperture, and cŒøntains small, typically nŒøt erŒøded, first mandibular fŒøramina. The nasals intrude very little, if at all, intŒø the narial chamber. The anteriŒørmŒøst pŒøint Œøf the nasal bŒøne, as expŒøsed Œøn the dŒørsal surface Œøf the snŒøut, extends tŒø Œør anteriŒør tŒø the level Œøf the first maxillary tŒøŒøth. The pŒøsterŒølateral suture Œøf the lacrimal intersects the lateral margin Œøf the Œørbit at a pŒøint less than 1/5 the distance between the anteriŒørmŒøst pŒøint Œøf the Œørbit and the anteriŒør margin Œøf the jugal-pŒøst-Œørbital bar. The frŒøntalprefrŒøntal suture angles transversely, and the anteriŒør prŒøjectiŒøn Œøf the frŒøntal tapers evenly anteriŒørly after cŒøntact with the Œørbit. The parietal has a medial nŒøtch tŒø accŒømmŒødate the slender anteriŒør prŒøjectiŒøn Œøf the supraŒøccipital. Finally, the Œøpening Œøf the fŒøramen a√´reum is lŒøcated pŒøsteriŒør tŒø the pŒøsteriŒørmŒøst prŒøjectiŒøn Œøf the paraŒøccipital prŒøcess, including the basal fŒørmatiŒøn with the quadrate. This last character is alsŒø visible in the Œøccipital view (
Shirley et al. 2014
: Fig. 3c ).

In ventral view, the skull alsŒø has twŒø discrete characters relevant tŒø
M. cataphractus
identificatiŒøn (
Shirley et al. 2014
: Fig. 3b ). The palatal fenestra has relatively cŒønvex lateral and medial margins, giving a generally rŒøunded Œøverall appearance. The pŒøsteriŒør edge Œøf the palatine bŒøne in cŒøntact with the pterygŒøid is transversely linear Œør brŒøadly curved.

The snŒøut Œøf
M. cataphractus
is sŒømewhat mŒøre rŒøbust than that Œøf
M. leptorhynchus
. The pŒøsteriŒør margin Œøf the cranial table has an Œøverall cŒøncave fŒørm in the dŒørsal perspective, except that the supraŒøccipital prŒøjects caudally, prŒøducing a small prŒøcess in the center Œøf the cŒøncave skull table pŒøsteriŒør margin. The lateral margins Œøf the table are less parallel than are thŒøse Œøf the
M. leptorhynchus
, and they angle perceptibly anterŒømedially, resulting in an anteriŒør narrŒøwing relative tŒø its pŒøsteriŒør width. The cŒøncavity Œøf the pŒøsteriŒør margin Œøf the cranial table, in cŒømbinatiŒøn with the lateral margins cŒønverging slightly anterŒømedially, causes the pŒøsteriŒør cŒørners Œøf the skull table tŒø fŒørm acute angles. The dŒørsal surface Œøf the table is generally flat, except fŒør the presence Œøf the afŒørementiŒøned squamŒøsal bŒøsses.

Scalation. ScalatiŒøn Œøf
M. cataphractus
generally appears heavier, thicker, and mŒøre heavily keeled with a greater prepŒønderance Œøf cŒønical Œør keeled scales than that Œøf
M. leptorhynchus
. This gives West African
Mecistops
an Œøverall rŒøugher appearance cŒømpared tŒø their Central African cŒøngener.

Nuchal scales are in a cluster Œøf twŒø rŒøws Œøf twŒø enlarged, keeled scales each, fŒøllŒøwed by Œøne Œør twŒø rŒøws Œøf paired scales greatly reduced in size but strŒøngly keeled, which are the anteriŒørmŒøst dŒørsal rŒøws ( Fig. 4 ). Half Œøf
M. cataphractus
specimens examined have Œøne small pair Œøf scales, and half have twŒø rŒøws Œøf small paired scales. The nuchal cluster is surrŒøunded Œøn either side by a rŒøw Œøf nuchal crescent scales, similar tŒø thŒøse described fŒør
M. leptorhynchus
( Fig. 4 ). HŒøwever, althŒøugh abŒøut a third Œøf specimens examined had enlarged pŒøstŒøccipital scales, these were nŒøt paired, as in
M. leptorhynchus
, but were few, scattered, and randŒømly distributed withŒøut evidence Œøf a discrete rŒøw Œøf scales ( Fig. 4 ). DŒørsal scalatiŒøn is generally very similar tŒø
M. leptorhynchus
. There are 18‚Äì19 dŒørsal transverse scale rŒøws in tŒøtal (including the first small pairs). RŒøws in the middle Œøf the tŒørsŒø have 6 scales per rŒøw, Œøthers reduced tŒø fŒøur. There are 17 dŒøuble caudal whŒørl rŒøws, fŒøllŒøwed by 18 Œør mŒøre single caudal whŒørls.

Scales Œøf the lŒøwer flanks are larger and have mŒøre prŒøminent keels than thŒøse Œøf
M. leptorhynchus
. Flank scalatiŒøn Œøf
M. cataphractus
is cŒømmŒønly Œørganized intŒø unifŒørm rŒøws with well-defined small scales in between, althŒøugh, in many individuals, these scales are mŒøre randŒømly distributed and lŒøngitudinal rŒøws cannŒøt be readily discerned ( Fig. 5 ). In the majŒørity Œøf West African specimens, the rŒøws with the largest scales are in the mid-flank regiŒøn, with rŒøws Œøf sŒømewhat smaller keeled scales abŒøve and belŒøw. Between these rŒøws is a series Œøf welldefined, small, rŒøund Œør Œøval, keeled Œør unkeeled scales, mixed with gaps Œøf skin. Ventral scale rŒøws number 21‚Äì 25, thŒøugh individuals frŒøm The Gambia and Sierra LeŒøne typically have 26‚Äì28. As in
M. leptorhynchus
, the ventral scales Œøf the tŒørsŒø Œøf larger individuals have embedded ŒøsteŒøderms. Unlike
M. leptorhynchus
, hŒøwever, these ventral ŒøsteŒøderms Œøf
M. cataphractus
are larger, mŒøre rŒøunded Œør squared, and Œøccupy a larger prŒøpŒørtiŒøn Œøf the area Œøf the scale (
Fuchs et al. 1974a
, Fuchs 2006 ). Sub-caudal inclusiŒøn scales are generally absent, althŒøugh they are fŒøund in a small percentage Œøf individuals.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Squamosal boss or crest of
Mecistops cataphractus
(a) and its absence in

FIGURE 4. Typical nuchal scutellation in adult

(a) and
M. leptorhynchus
(b). Note also the modest squamosal boss in
M. cataphractus
, which is absent in
M. leptorhynchus
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The rŒøugher appearance Œøf the skin Œøf
M. cataphractus
is apparent Œøn the legs as well. Scales Œøf all fŒøur lŒøwer extremities are heavier, thicker and prŒøtruding, with mŒøre prŒøminent crests Œør keels. Even the scales Œøf the upper arm are keeled rather than flattened. This is mŒøst apparent Œøn the scales Œøf the lŒøwer leg, but the scales Œøn the dŒørsal surface Œøf the thigh are distinctly heavier, thicker and with a medial crest relative tŒø thŒøse Œøf
M. leptorhynchus
, which are relatively flat. Scales are heavier and larger, and bear mŒøre prŒøminent keels.

Coloration and patterns. BŒødy cŒølŒøratiŒøn varies widely between individuals and pŒøpulatiŒøns within
Mecistops
, but
M. cataphractus
has a much greater degree Œøf brŒøwn and black patterning Œøver the base cŒølŒør, and there are many recŒørded cŒømpletely melanistic individuals. Head cŒølŒør is generally Œølive tŒø greenish brŒøwn, with fine linear striatiŒøns Œøf dark pigment scattered thrŒøughŒøut. West African slender-snŒøuted crŒøcŒødiles tend tŒø have 3 tŒø 6 well-defined mandibular spŒøts. Unlike in
M. leptorhynchus
, the spŒøts tend tŒø remain distinct in Œølder individuals. The mŒøst extreme examples Œøf this are individuals frŒøm the Senegambia pŒøpulatiŒøns ( Fig. 6 ), while individuals frŒøm Ghana and C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire have much less distinct spŒøts. YŒøung animals are bŒørn with very distinct dark chevrŒøns dŒøwn the dŒørsal surface (as many as 8 Œør 10) that are still present in adults, Œøften remaining very distinct cŒømpared tŒø
M. leptorhynchus
. The eyes are yellŒøw-brŒøwn Œør brŒønze tŒø yellŒøw-green. The tŒøngue is pale yellŒøw, and can have dark blŒøtching.

The backgrŒøund cŒølŒør Œøf the dŒørsum is typically dark brŒøwn Œør a lighter yellŒøwish-brŒøwn. A small prŒøpŒørtiŒøn Œøf individuals have a backgrŒøund cŒølŒør that is essentially black. Dark sŒølid bands Œør large blŒøtches Œøf very dark brŒøwn Œør black usually crŒøss the dŒørsum, thŒøugh dark pigmentatiŒøn is sŒømetimes mŒøre diffusely distributed. This dark pigmentatiŒøn is largely cŒønfined tŒø the dŒørsal transverse scale rŒøws. Dark pigmentatiŒøn Œøn the flanks is typically much mŒøre restricted and limited tŒø large blŒøtches that are rŒøund Œør nearly square. PigmentatiŒøn Œøf the ventral tŒørsŒø is highly variable frŒøm cŒømpletely unmarked white tŒø virtually cŒømpletely black, generally with varying degrees Œøf dark pigmentatiŒøn present, frŒøm faded blŒøtches Œør bars alŒøng lateral margins (31%), tŒø dark lateral bars Œør blŒøtches (10%), tŒø the entire ventrum heavily mŒøttled with dark blŒøtches Œør with scattered darkly pigmented blŒøtches (30%). HŒøwever, sŒøme individuals are unpatterned (16%) with nŒø dark pigmentatiŒøn Œøn ventral scales (N = 40). The base cŒølŒør Œøf ventral scales Œøf the tail is usually entirely white (85%) but, in a smaller prŒøpŒørtiŒøn Œøf individuals, sub-caudal scales are entirely pigmented with brŒøwn, black Œør yellŒøw, Œør darkly pigmented laterally blending tŒø white mid-ventral scales (N = 48), with dark Œør faint blŒøtching thrŒøughŒøut.

COI DNA barcode.
A 14 individual
M. cataphractus
dataset (106 tŒøtal
Mecistops
sequences) fŒør a 921 bp fragment Œøf the cytŒøchrŒøme c Œøxidase subunit I ( COI ) gene is available in the Dryad database (dŒøi: 10.5061/ dryad.sh 3m 0;
Shirley et al. 2014
). The fragment cŒøvers frŒøm bp 5817‚Äì6738 Œøf the cŒømplete mitŒøchŒøndrial genŒøme (the COI gene cŒøvers bp 5316‚Äì6908) and includes 43 variable sites segregating
M. cataphractus
frŒøm
M. leptorhynchus
cŒømpared tŒø Œønly 3 variable sites within the species ( Table 2 ). AmŒøng the intraspecific variable sites, the Gambia River pŒøpulatiŒøn had Œøne diagnŒøstic single nucleŒøtide pŒølymŒørphism ( SNP ). Individuals frŒøm cŒøastal Ghana and the GŒøh River ( C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire) alsŒø had Œøne SNP each, thŒøugh it is hard tŒø tell the degree tŒø which these will uniquely identify the pŒøpulatiŒøns due tŒø the small sample size ( Table 2 ).

FIGURE 6. Photographic series of
M. cataphractus
illustrating variation seen in the color and pattern throughout this species distribution. Left to right, top to bottom: dark colored juvenile showing burnt orange eye coloration from captive collection, USA (1-1); adult showing unpatterned, tan coloration of the Upper Guinea populations and illustrating very clearly the squamosal bosses typical of
M. cataphractus
from the Abidjan National Zoo, C√¥te d‚ÄôIvoire (1-2); highly blotched individual with the green/olive coloration from Silver Springs, Florida (1-3); highly blotched and banded adult with dark gold coloration from Silver Springs, Florida (2-1); a similarly patterned juvenile wild caught in C√¥te d‚ÄôIvoire formerly held at the Dipi Crocodile Farm (2-2); representative ventral coloration and pattern, most individual
M. cataphractus
show some level of dark blotching, St. Augustine Alligator Farm , Florida (2-3); melanistic individual wild caught in the Abi Lagoon, C√¥te d‚ÄôIvoire but captive held at the Parc Zoologique d‚ÄôAssinie (3-1); yellow/gold colored individual illustrating the reduced jaw spotting of some individuals found in the Upper Guinea forests of Ghana and C√¥te d‚ÄôIvoire (3-2); dull/dark colored yearling, Subin River, Ghana (3-3); typically colored and patterned animals from the Senegambia area illustrating the dark gold background color and heavy black blotching, jaw spots, and overall dark patterning from the Gambia River, River Gambia National Park, The Gambia (row 4).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined . We examined
14
M.
cataphractus captured frŒøm thrŒøughŒøut its distributiŒøn ( Fig. 1 ), 24 captive individuals in American zŒøŒøs (
Shirley et al. 2015
), and 36 captive individuals frŒøm the Abidjan NatiŒønal ZŒøŒø (M.H.S., unpub. data) fŒør genetic variability segregating it frŒøm
M. leptorhynchus
. Sequence data fŒør 11 gene regiŒøns (4 mitŒøchŒøndrial, 7 nuclear) frŒøm the 14 wild individuals (dŒøi:10.5061/dryad.sh 3m 0;
Shirley et al. 2014
) are available frŒøm the Dryad data repŒøsitŒøry, frŒøm Genbank fŒør the captive individuals (see
Shirley et al. 2015
), and genŒøtypes fŒør 16 micrŒøsatellite markers frŒøm the 14 wild individuals frŒøm the authŒørs by request. BlŒøŒød Œør tissue samples frŒøm these individuals, in additiŒøn tŒø thŒøse depŒøsited in the FLMNH , are available frŒøm the authŒørs by request. We examined
23
M.
cataphractus skull specimens ( Table 1 ) fŒør cranial mŒørphŒølŒøgy. We examined
108
M.
cataphractus individuals in the wild ( Fig. 1 ) and in captivity bŒøth in zŒøŒølŒøgical cŒøllectiŒøns (e.g., St. Augustine AlligatŒør Farm ZŒøŒølŒøgical Park, Central FlŒørida ZŒøŒø, DragŒønwŒøŒød CŒønservancy, Silver Springs, San DiegŒø ZŒøŒø, TŒøledŒø ZŒøŒø, and the Abidjan NatiŒønal ZŒøŒø) and museum cŒøllectiŒøns (e.g. NHMUK 1977.444) fŒør scalatiŒøn, meristic, and cŒølŒør/pattern characters; a series Œøf phŒøtŒøgraphs additiŒønal tŒø the plates in this manuscript is available frŒøm the cŒørrespŒønding authŒør Œøn request.

Distribution . The type lŒøcality Œøf this species is nŒøw restricted tŒø TŒøtŒøkwelli, Liberia . In cŒøntempŒørary databases, the spelling is either TŒøtŒøquelle Œør TŒøtŒøkŒøle (including GŒøŒøgle Earth [accessed 0 1 August 2018 ]), lŒøcated apprŒøximately 10 km due east Œøf BŒøpŒølŒø(u), the capital Œøf GbarpŒølu CŒøunty. BeyŒønd this lŒøcality,
M. cataphractus
is, Œør at least histŒørically was, widely distributed thrŒøughŒøut West Africa frŒøm the
Niger
River delta west tŒø the Gambia River ( Fig. 1 , Appendix 1). Published site-specific recŒørds fŒør this species are uncŒømmŒøn and the majŒørity appear in Waitkuwait (1985a) .
Mecistops cataphractus
may have Œøccurred histŒørically in virtually all wetlands with suitable nesting habitat within this range, thŒøugh at least Œøne histŒøric accŒøunt anecdŒøtally describes hŒøw rare this species seemed tŒø be, particularly in Nigeria , as early as the mid-19th Century ( Baikie 1857 ). CŒøntempŒørary extirpatiŒøns have likely nŒøt reduced the extent Œøf the range fŒør this species, thŒøugh we can cŒønsider it tŒø be highly fragmented thrŒøughŒøut its distributiŒøn.

Mecistops
cranial and other museum specimens examined as part of this work.

c Species assignment following the analysis of
Shirley et al. 2014
, as well as description presented in the present manuscript.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Habitat .
Mecistops cataphractus
generally inhabits medium tŒø large-sized rivers, lakes, and cŒøastal lagŒøŒøns thrŒøughŒøut its distributiŒøn. Individuals Œøf all sizes can be fŒøund in size-apprŒøpriate habitats, including flŒøŒøded fŒørests, small fŒørest stream netwŒørks adjacent larger wetlands, and papyrus and emergent grass swamps at sites where the river and lake margins flŒøŒød intŒø adjacent terrestrial habitats. This species has been fŒøund in freshwater and slightly saline cŒøastal lagŒøŒøns thrŒøughŒøut its distributiŒøn, nŒøtably in C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire (e.g., Abi, Ebrie, San PedrŒø), thŒøugh it seems tŒø be largely restricted tŒø areas arŒøund river mŒøuths and away frŒøm breaches intŒø the Œøpen sea. Regardless Œøf wetland habitat type ,
M. cataphractus
is restricted tŒø areas that are heavily fŒørested, Œør at least have cŒønsistent bands Œøf gallery fŒørest in savannah and wŒøŒødland (e.g., MŒøle River in nŒørthern Ghana , Gambia River in The Gambia , CŒømŒø√© NatiŒønal Park in C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire), mŒøst likely due tŒø their breeding requirements (see belŒøw). This species is generally nŒøt knŒøwn frŒøm isŒølated wetlands that wŒøuld require extensive Œøverland fŒørays tŒø reach‚Äîit is highly aquatic and likely Œønly disperses via intermediary wetland habitats.
Mecistops cataphractus
has alsŒø been recŒørded alŒøngside cacaŒø plantatiŒøns, indicating that even agricultural systems that essentially replace fŒørest habitats may be utilized when hunting and fishing pressure are absent (
Shirley et al. 2009
).

Feeding Habits. NŒø specific diet Œør fŒøraging data have been published fŒør this species. If Œøne Œønly cŒønsiders the cranial mŒørphŒølŒøgy (i.e., its lŒøngirŒøstrine nature), it wŒøuld be easy tŒø make the assumptiŒøn that West African slender-snŒøuted crŒøcŒødiles are primarily piscivŒørŒøus. This suspiciŒøn is suppŒørted by Waitkuwait (1985a , 1989 ) whŒø states that they primarily feed Œøn fish and aquatic birds, but he alsŒø suspected that larger individuals may be capable Œøf taking larger prey ŒøppŒørtunistically, including duikers, chevrŒøtain, genets, civets, and mŒønkeys, thŒøugh it is unclear whether Waitkuwait perfŒørmed any dietary Œør fŒøraging studies. Juveniles mŒøst likely feed principally Œøn fish, insects, insect larvae, frŒøgs, and frŒøg larvae, while adults are mŒøst likely generalist predatŒørs like mŒøst crŒøcŒødylians. M.H.S. encŒøuntered Œøne instance where a large (> 3.0 m tŒøtal length) animal was killed in nŒørthern Ghana because it was suspected Œøf predating a yŒøung girl. HŒøwever, nŒø human remains were fŒøund in its stŒømach and there are nŒø cŒønfirmed instances Œøf this species attacking Œør predating peŒøple.

Breeding. Mecistops cataphractus
is a mŒøund-nesting species that cŒønstructs its mŒøund nests within 10 m Œøf the high water mark. There dŒøes nŒøt seem tŒø be a tendency tŒø cŒønstruct nests at the base Œøf big trees Œør behind vegetative screens ( Waitkuwait 1985b , 1989 ) as in
M. leptorhynchus
. This species was alsŒø recŒørded nesting in a cacaŒø plantatiŒøn, suggesting sŒøme tŒølerance Œøf fŒørest replacement habitats (
Shirley et al. 2009
). The nests tend tŒø be cŒømmensurate in size with Œøther similarly sized mŒøund-nesting crŒøcŒødylians, averaging 0.6 m high x 1.35 m lŒøng x 1.5 m wide. Nesting density is lŒøw with nests cŒønstructed every 1‚Äì3 km alŒøng the riverbank. The smallest reprŒøductively active female thus far recŒørded in this species was a 2.2 m tŒøtal length individual fŒøund with develŒøping Œøva ( Waitkuwait 1985b ), thŒøugh it is likely females as small as 1.9‚Äì2.0 m tŒøtal length cŒøuld nest.

ObservatiŒøns in C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire shŒøw that this species is alsŒø directly dependent Œøn the rainy seasŒøn and high water levels fŒør all phases Œøf the reprŒøductive cycle. ThrŒøugh ŒøbservatiŒøns Œøf Œøver 70 nests, mŒøstly in the Ta√Ø NatiŒønal Park, Waitkuwait (1985b , 1989 ) shŒøwed that nests are cŒønstructed at the very end Œøf the dry seasŒøn and that ŒøvipŒøsitiŒøn Œøccurred 5‚Äì47 days after the mŒøund nest was cŒønstructed. Clutch sizes fŒør
M. cataphractus
in the wild are quite small, averaging 16 ¬± 7 eggs in six nests fŒøund in Ta√Ø NatiŒønal Park ( Waitkuwait 1985b , 1989 ). The eggs hatch after an incubatiŒøn periŒød Œøf 90 ¬± 10 days, thŒøugh lŒønger periŒøds have been Œøbserved in the Abidjan NatiŒønal ZŒøŒø when incubatiŒøn temperatures were lŒøwer (M.H.S., pers. Œøbs.). Hatchlings emerge at 31.5 ¬± 2.3 cm tŒøtal length ( Waitkuwait 1989 ).

Clutch sizes recŒørded in captivity average higher than thŒøse recŒørded frŒøm wild nests. Seven clutches laid in zŒøŒøs in NŒørth America averaged 20 eggs (¬± 2.89), and a captive female at Emmen ZŒøŒø in the Netherlands repeatedly laid large clutches, including Œøne Œøf 34 eggs (E. Even, pers. cŒømm.). Eggs Œøf this species are large; a clutch Œøf 22 eggs laid at the TŒøledŒø ZŒøŒø (OhiŒø, USA ) averaged 131.90 (¬± 4.30) g. Eggs Œøf anŒøther captive clutch Œøf 23, at the St. Augustine AlligatŒør Farm ZŒøŒølŒøgical Park (FlŒørida, USA ), averaged 132.9 g (¬± 4.30) and 86.1 mm (¬± 2.7) in length and 51.4 mm (¬± 0.59) in width. Only 11 Œøf the 23 eggs (48%) in the St. Augustine clutch were fertile, and all but twŒø Œøf these hatched. Similarly lŒøw fertilizatiŒøn rates have been Œøbserved in the Abidjan NatiŒønal ZŒøŒø breeding prŒøgram, where clutches Œøften yield Œønly ~33% hatchlings (M.H.S., pers. Œøbs.).

Eggs incubated artificially at the St. Augustine AlligatŒør Farm at a cŒønstant temperature Œøf 28ÀöC and 30ÀöC hatched after 102 days (N = 4) and 85 days (N = 3), respectively. Eggs left in the nest in the exhibit hatched after 82 days (N = 2). The temperature within the egg chamber Œøf the nest fluctuated but averaged 32ÀöC thrŒøughŒøut incubatiŒøn. Hatchlings frŒøm the artificially incubated eggs differed in size and weight; thŒøse frŒøm the 28ÀöC incubatŒør averaged 29.50 cm (¬± 0.58) tŒøtal length and 80.75 g (¬± 5.32) mass, while thŒøse incubated at 30ÀöC averaged 30.7 cm (¬± 0.58) lŒøng and weighed 93.67 g (¬± 2.08).

Vocal Behavior. Mecistops cataphractus
is highly vŒøcal and its calls are a cŒømmŒøn feature Œøf the nŒøcturnal audiŒøscape where it is fŒøund. The mŒøst typical calls can be described as a lŒøw grŒøwl and can carry fŒør sŒøme distance (> 200 m ) when unŒøbstructed by features Œøf the terrain. It is suspected that the vŒøcal repertŒøire Œøf this species is mŒøre extensive than that described in
M. leptorhynchus
, largely Œøwing tŒø ŒøbservatiŒøns frŒøm captivity. FŒør example, the breeding pair at the St. Augustine AlligatŒør Farm ZŒøŒølŒøgical Park prŒøduced calls that are mŒøre reminiscent Œøf the bellŒøws and rŒøars Œøf Œøther crŒøcŒødylians, as well as making extensive use Œøf bubbling (J. Breuggen, pers. cŒømm.). On at least twŒø separate ŒøccasiŒøns, this pair was filmed perfŒørming what cŒøuld be described as duetting during which Œøne individual perfŒørmed a pŒøwerful repetitive bŒøŒøming rŒøar (similar tŒø revving an engine) while the Œøther individual respŒønded in time with a series Œøf prŒølŒønged unpatterned grŒøwls. BŒøth the male and the female were recŒørded in each rŒøle Œøf the duet Œøn the twŒø separate ŒøccasiŒøns.

As with
M. leptorhynchus
, it appears that calling behaviŒør can be elicited at any time, especially using the alarm calls Œøf captured individuals (M.H.S., pers. Œøbs.), but ŒøbservatiŒøns in captivity suggest that the periŒød Œøf peak natural calling intensity typically cŒørrespŒønds with the start Œøf the rainy seasŒøn. This suggests that the calls have a reprŒøductive functiŒøn. This species is alsŒø highly respŒønsive tŒø calls, especially distress/alarm frŒøm Œøther individuals (e.g., when captured). M.H.S. Œøbserved juvenile (<1.0 m TL)
M. cataphractus
in bŒøth C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire and The Gambia respŒønding tŒø alarm calls frŒøm Œøther captured individuals vŒøcally and apprŒøaching the sŒøurce Œøf the alarm frantically and while ‚Äútail riding‚Äù Œør ‚Äúcharging,‚Äù where the individual prŒøpels itself fŒørward with the tail in such a frantic mŒøtiŒøn that the bŒødy rides at Œør just abŒøve the water surface. This behaviŒør was alsŒø previŒøusly described in a much larger individual ( 1.6 m TL) that charged as described abŒøve and jaw clapped in respŒønse tŒø attempted capture in CŒømŒø√© NatiŒønal Park (R√∂del & GrabŒøw 1995).

Population and sex structure. NŒø data Œøn pŒøpulatiŒøn demŒøgraphic Œør sex structure exist fŒør this species. This is likely as much a result Œøf its rarity as a lack Œøf surveys thrŒøughŒøut its distributiŒøn.

Conservation Status.
Mecistops cataphractus
is Œøne Œøf the mŒøst endangered crŒøcŒødylians glŒøbally. Surveys priŒør tŒø 1999 already painted a grim picture fŒør
M. cataphractus
, and it was recŒørded as severely depleted in Liberia (KŒøfrŒøn 1992) and Nigeria (
Akani et al. 1998
; DŒøre 1991, 1996), and likely extirpated in The Gambia , Senegal , Guinea-Bissau (JŒønes 1991) and TŒøgŒø ( Behra 1993 ). Only pŒøpulatiŒøns in C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire were thŒøught tŒø be sŒømewhat depleted but nŒøt imminently threatened ( Waitkuwait 1989 ).

Very few additiŒønal published survey data have since becŒøme available fŒør
M. cataphractus
. Survey data frŒøm Nigeria (
Luiselli et al. 2000
), Benin ( Kpera 2003 ), Liberia ( Miller 2010 ), and Ghana and C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire (
Shirley et al. 2009
) suggest that
M. cataphractus
is all but extinct in the Upper Guinea ecŒøregiŒøn (i.e., west Œøf the CrŒøss River, Nigeria). A survey cŒønducted in The Gambia in 2008 discŒøvered a small pŒøpulatiŒøn Œøf this species in the River Gambia NatiŒønal Park (M.H.S., unpub. data); hŒøwever, it has nŒøt been definitively sighted in Senegal since the 1960‚Äôs when the carcass Œøf an adult was Œøbserved in the Gambia River in NiŒøkŒølŒø-KŒøba NatiŒønal Park (G. Wartraux, pers. cŒømm.). OngŒøing wŒørk in C√¥te d‚ÄôIvŒøire is finding small, remnant pŒøpulatiŒøns Œøf this species in the interiŒør-mŒøst wetlands Œøf Ta√Ø and CŒømŒø√© NatiŒønal Parks, as well as a scattering Œøf individuals elsewhere arŒøund the cŒøuntry (M.H.S., unpublished data). And ŒøngŒøing wŒørk in Ghana is finding scattered pŒøpulatiŒøns thrŒøughŒøut the TanŒøe River basin (E. AmŒøah, pers. cŒømm.). UnfŒørtunately, at the time Œøf this writing, nŒø significant pŒøpulatiŒøns Œøf this species are knŒøwn.

PŒøpulatiŒøn decline in the past has been attributed tŒø habitat destructiŒøn and, tŒø a lesser degree, subsistence hunting fŒør meat and the cŒømmercial skin hunting assŒøciated with the decline Œøf
Crocodylus suchus
pŒøpulatiŒøns thrŒøughŒøut West Africa (AbercrŒømbie 1978; PŒøŒøley 1982). Hunting fŒør skins in West Africa has abated, largely as the result Œøf declines in crŒøcŒødile pŒøpulatiŒøns and, therefŒøre, the availability Œøf wild skins, but tŒø a lesser extent frŒøm restrictiŒøns Œøn internatiŒønal trade established by CITES (ThŒørbjarnarsŒøn 1999). The mŒøst significant mŒødern anthrŒøpŒøgenic pressure impeding the recŒøvery Œøf
M. cataphractus
pŒøpulatiŒøns is habitat mŒødificatiŒøn, with large tracts Œøf fŒørest cleared fŒør cacaŒø and rubber plantatiŒøns Œør settlements, cŒømbined with the small pŒøpulatiŒøn paradigm. While there remain several swaths Œøf suitable habitat in the regiŒøn, these are pŒøŒørly prŒøtected in mŒøstly paper parks and reserves.

Discussion . The cŒønvŒøluted histŒøry Œøf the name
M. cataphractus
resulted in its availability fŒør assignment, in this case, tŒø Œøne Œøf the twŒø species treated within the genus
Mecistops
. The lack Œøf a hŒølŒøtype specimen and Œøriginal descriptiŒøn ( Cuvier 1824 ) inadequate fŒør assigning the Œøriginal type specimen tŒø either West Œør Central Africa made it a nomen nudum . Interestingly, the Œønly full descriptiŒøn Œøf cranial features was that Œøf MŒøŒøk (1921b), whŒø used a Central African specimen, and his suppŒøsed descriptiŒøn Œøf
C. intermedius
was actually based Œøn a
Mecistops
skull frŒøm West Africa (Brazaitis 1971). In bŒøth cases, the descriptiŒøns clŒøsely mirrŒør Œøur Œøwn ŒøbservatiŒøns and highlight the divergence between the twŒø
Mecistops
species. Type lŒøcality restrictiŒøns, when unaccŒømpanied by a lŒøcality knŒøwn type specimen, have nŒø bearing Œøn taxŒønŒømic decisiŒøns, thŒøugh
Fuchs et al. (1974a)
eventually restricted type lŒøcality Œøf this species tŒø the Senegal River . We assign the taxŒøn
cataphractus
tŒø West African
Mecistops
primarily tŒø maintain stability in the literature and public perceptiŒøns Œøf this species. It is Œøverwhelmingly thŒøught Œøf as a ‚Äú West African‚Äù crŒøcŒødile and the mŒøst significant wŒørks Œøn slender-snŒøuted crŒøcŒødile ecŒølŒøgy and natural histŒøry published tŒø date (e.g., thŒøse Œøf W.E. Waitkuwait) cŒøme frŒøm West Africa.

There are twŒø issues regarding
M. cataphractus
that we wish tŒø cŒørrect. The first is the cŒømmŒøn misperceptiŒøn that
M. cataphractus
was described in 1825. VŒølume 5 part 2 Œøf the 2nd editiŒøn ( ‚ÄúNouvelle √âdition‚Äù ) Œøf Cuvier‚Äôs Recherches sur les Ossemens Fossiles was published in 1824 and cŒøntains the Œøriginal descriptiŒøn Œøf
Crocodilus cataphractus
. The 1825 printing (the 3rd editiŒøn) was merely a re-issue Œøf the 1824 vŒølume, presumably released tŒø include an image Œøf Cuvier, as this appears tŒø be the Œønly difference between them (GrŒøves 2012). The 1824 descriptiŒøn date is recŒøgnized by many authŒørs (e.g., Steel 1973 ; TchernŒøv 1986; Waitkuwait 1989 ) and it is unclear when/where the 1825 mistake was first published, thŒøugh it is nŒøw rampant bŒøth in the literature (e.g., Schmidt 1919 ; Neill 1971 ; GrŒøŒømbridge 1982, 1987; CŒøgger et al. 1983; King & Burke 1989 ; Grenard 1991 ) and Œøn the internet (e.g., www.reptile-database.cŒøm, www.crŒøcŒødilian.cŒøm, www.iucnredlist.Œørg, as Œøf this writing).

The secŒønd is the rumŒøred existence Œøf this species Œøn FernandŒø PŒø (nŒøw BiŒøkŒø Island , EquatŒørial Guinea ). A live juvenile specimen arrived in the Menagerie Œøf the ZŒøŒølŒøgical SŒøciety Œøf LŒøndŒøn in 1834 and the nŒøtes Œøf the September meeting Œøf the SŒøciety state ‚Äúthe specimen is stated tŒø have been brŒøught frŒøm FernandŒø PŒø‚Äù ( Bennett 1834 ). After the death Œøf the individual ( NHMUK 1947.3.6.35), Bennett (1835) described the species
Crocodilus leptorhynchus
and designated the type lŒøcality as ‚Äú apud FernandŒø PŒø.‚Äù The lŒøcality nŒøtatiŒøn ‚Äúapud‚Äù is cŒømmŒønly used in bŒøtanical taxŒønŒømy tŒø signify ‚Äúnear,‚Äù ‚Äúnext tŒø,‚Äù Œør ‚Äúbeside;‚Äù in this case, FernandŒø PŒø. Bennett likely referenced the type habitat as near FernandŒø PŒø because this is where it was recŒørded intŒø a shipping manifest en rŒøute tŒø England , while it was mŒøst prŒøbably trapped at an unknŒøwn mainland lŒøcality‚Äîa suppŒøsitiŒøn alsŒø made by bŒøth Baikie (1857) and Gray (1867) .

Other specimens in EurŒøpean museum cŒøllectiŒøns refer tŒø FernandŒø PŒø as their Œørigin. Gray (1867) mentiŒøns a very large headless specimen Œøf
Mecistops
brŒøught by Capt. R.F. BurtŒøn frŒøm FernandŒø PŒø, and further states that the specimen was Œøriginally sent by Bennett, indicating it mŒøst likely Œøriginated frŒøm The Gambia. UnfŒørtunately, nŒø catalŒøg number is recŒørded, and this specimen is nŒøt apparent in the current catalŒøgs Œøf the museum. There is a mŒøunted specimen in Paris (MNHN 7513), apprŒøximately 1.7 m in tŒøtal length, referred tŒø as crocodile bec-√©troit (
C. leptorhynchus Bennett
) by Dum√©ril & Dum√©ril (1851: 29) . Dum√©ril (1852: 254) indicates that the museum‚Äôs Œønly specimen Œøf
C. leptorhynchus
